title: 115_s1536
content: The "Combating Human Trafficking in Commercial Vehicles Act" designates a Human Trafficking Prevention Coordinator within the Department of Transportation to coordinate efforts across different transportation modes and with other government agencies. It also expands outreach and education programs to support the recognition, prevention, and reporting of human trafficking. SEC. 4. EXPANSION OF COMMERCIAL DRIVER'S LICENSE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. Amends Section 31313(a)(3) of title 49, United States Code to provide additional support for the recognition, prevention, and reporting of human trafficking. SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HUMAN TRAFFICKING. Requires the Secretary to establish an advisory committee on human trafficking. The Department of Transportation Advisory Committee on Human Trafficking shall consist of up to 15 external stakeholders appointed by the Secretary, representing various sectors such as trafficking advocacy organizations, law enforcement, and transportation industries. Members serve for the life of the Committee and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Committee members serve without compensation. The Department of Transportation Advisory Committee on Human Trafficking, composed of up to 15 external stakeholders, serves without compensation. The Committee is tasked with making recommendations to combat human trafficking within 18 months of enactment, including strategies for identification, reporting, and legislative changes. The Department of Transportation Advisory Committee on Human Trafficking, composed of external stakeholders, develops best practices for combating human trafficking based on research and evidence-based models. These practices include sample training materials, victim identification strategies, and protocols. Strategies to collect, document, and share data across systems and agencies, understand types of trafficking, scope of the problem, victim interaction, and identify effective pathways for State agencies to educate stakeholder groups and assist victims. The Secretary will inform State Governors and departments of transportation about best practices and recommendations. A report on the Committee's actions must be submitted to specific Senate and House committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment, and made publicly available. The term "Committee" refers to the Department of Transportation Advisory Committee on Human Trafficking. The Transportation Advisory Committee on Human Trafficking is established under the Secretary of Transportation. Human trafficking is defined as acts described in the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000.
